intro: Peucedanum salmoniflorum, commonly known as the salmonflower cowparsley, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. It is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia and is known for its delicate, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, with finely divided leaves that resemble those of other parsley relatives. Its root system is fibrous, and it thrives in well-drained, loamy soils. The plant is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has a mild, spicy scent reminiscent of anise and fennel.
